hints_html: Evaluate the derivative at y first. Remember to treat the other variable as a constant.
hints_latex:
Evaluate the derivative at \emph{y} first. Remember to treat the other
variable as a constant.
hints_raw: Evaluate the derivative at ''y'' first. Remember to treat the other variable as a constant.
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
Taking the derivative of \(\displaystyle f(x,y) = (2x+y^{3})^{10}\) with respect to y using the chain rule gives

\(\displaystyle \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} = 10(2x + y^{3})^{9}(3y^{2})\)

Then taking this function’s derivative with respect to x using the chain rule gives

\(\displaystyle \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y \partial x} = 90(3y^{2})(2x + y^{3})^{8}(2) = 540y^{2}(2x + y^{3})^{8}\)
sols_latex:
Taking the derivative of $\displaystyle f(x,y) = (2x+y^{3})^{10}$ with
respect to \emph{y} using the chain rule gives

$\displaystyle \frac{\partial f}{\partial y} = 10(2x + y^{3})^{9}(3y^{2})$

Then taking this function's derivative with respect to \emph{x} using
the chain rule gives

$\displaystyle \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y \partial x} = 90(3y^{2})(2x + y^{3})^{8}(2) = 540y^{2}(2x + y^{3})^{8}$
sols_raw:
Taking the derivative of <math> \displaystyle f(x,y) = (2x+y^{3})^{10} </math> with respect to ''y'' using the chain rule gives

<math> \displaystyle
\frac{\partial f}{\partial y} = 10(2x + y^{3})^{9}(3y^{2})
 </math>

Then taking this function's derivative with respect to ''x'' using the chain rule gives

<math> \displaystyle
\frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y \partial x} = 90(3y^{2})(2x + y^{3})^{8}(2) = 540y^{2}(2x + y^{3})^{8}
 </math>
statement_html: Let \(\displaystyle f(x,y) = (2x+y^{3})^{10}\). Evaluate \(\displaystyle \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y \partial x}\).
statement_latex:
Let $\displaystyle f(x,y) = (2x+y^{3})^{10}$. Evaluate
$\displaystyle \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y \partial x}$.
statement_raw: Let <math> \displaystyle f(x,y) = (2x+y^{3})^{10} </math>. Evaluate <math> \displaystyle \frac{\partial^{2} f}{\partial y \partial x}</math>.
